post_text:
I built the fastest permissions service ever. We all paid.
I believed heavily in separation of concerns. The AuthZ Service was designed to decouple complex security logic from our application features.

Our goal was a centralized, performant source of truth. I focused intensely on P99 latency, pruning the API contract down to only essential fields. This rigid definition seemed like robust defensive programming.

Six months later, a major marketing initiative spiked traffic 4x overnight. We immediately needed to integrate a new, time-sensitive permission attribute.

Changing the service required five downstream teams to update their clients immediately. Their disparate deployment timelines created unavoidable dependency drift. We saw cascading failures and stale data due to cache invalidation logic mismatching across the ecosystem.

The contract became a shared liability we couldn't unilaterally service.

What this taught me 👇
We had optimized solely for speed of access, forgetting the critical need for independent speed of change 🧩.

#backend #engineering #software #java
lesson_extracted: The operational cost of an API contract is always proportional to the number of teams you force to coordinate simultaneous deploys.
